title: Love Island doctor forced Amy Hart to eat after split with Curtis
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Love Island star Amy Hart has revealed she completely lost her appetite after splitting with Curtis Pritchard on the show and was forced into eating by the reality TV show’s resident doctor.

Amy revealed there was a whole team of support staff to come into the villa and check how much food and water contestants were having and how they were in general.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But the 27-year-old flight attendant also said ITV’s mental health team are ‘very, very thorough’ with checking in since finishing up on the show.

‘When it all went t*** up for me and I was lying in bed crying at lunchtime, [the welfare rep] would get into bed with me and just stroke my head and talk to me,’ Amy revealed.

Amy Hart and Curtis Pritchard were dating on Love Island 2019 (Pictures: (L) David M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty Images (R) HGL/Getty Images)

‘Now I speak to her on the phone twice a week to check how I am.’

She then added: ‘We’ve been given 18 months of sessions as mandatory from ITV and then we can have more if we want them afterwards.’

‘I’m very unorganised and busy at the moment so I let my psyche sessions go and [my welfare rep] ended up phoning my manager and saying, “We need to get a date in Amy’s diary when she’s free” so they are really on it,’ Amy added.

Amy was paired up with Curtis on the show but things turned sour when he tried to crack on with another girl in the villa.

The former air hostess eventually decided to leave the show because she was too heartbroken to go on and couldn’t bear to see Curtis moving on with current girlfriend Maura.

Curtis Pritchard and Amy Hart were a couple on Love Island (Picture: ITV)

Amy also opened up about her mental health struggles before and after filming the show.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I have had mental health issues in the past but I was reluctant to accept it,’ she said.

‘I didn’t admit that I had anxiety until a couple of years after I first started my job flying at British Airways.’

She added: ‘My previous anxiety issues manifested within food.

‘I would order the biggest dinner you’ve ever seen and take one bite and start shaking, crying and saying I can’t eat this anymore.’

‘I felt like wasn’t in control of the rest of my life – I was convinced I was going to get sacked, so food was my control thing,’ she said.

Amy revealed she lost a stone in her first six months at BA so when things went sour with Curtis, she experienced a similar thing.

She said: ‘ITV stepped in and made me eat as the psyche was watching me all the time.’

Read the full interview with Heat on 8 October.
